articles.author: Daphne Psaledakis, Nidal Al-Mughrabi
articles.description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said on Tuesday a Hamas statement of support for a U.N. resolution backing a proposal for a ceasefire in the Gaza war was a "hopeful sign" though word from the militant group's leadership in the enclave was vital.
articles.title: Blinken says Hamas signal of support for UN-backed Gaza truce deal is 'hopeful sign'

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: The airplane carrying Malawi's Vice President Saulos Klaus Chilima may have crashed in dense forest, but it has not yet been found, the military said on Tuesday.
articles.title: Malawi vice president's plane may have crashed in forest, military says

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's appeal against extradition from Britain to the United States will be heard next month, court officials in London said on Tuesday.
articles.title: WikiLeaks' Assange extradition appeal to be heard next month

articles.author: John O'Donnell
articles.description: Ukraine's army has struck missile launch positions in Russia, helping to reduce the number of attacks on the embattled city of Kharkiv, its mayor told Reuters on Tuesday.
articles.title: Exclusive: Kharkiv mayor says striking Russia has helped to calm embattled city

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: France's opposition left-wing parties late on Monday pledged to work together and nominate joint candidates in snap parliament elections later this month to challenge the government and Marine Le Pen's far-right movement.
articles.title: French left-wing parties pledge to team up for snap elections

articles.author: Guy Faulconbridge
articles.description: Russia said on Tuesday its troops had started the second stage of drills to practise the deployment of tactical nuclear weapons alongside Belarusian troops after what Moscow said were threats from Western powers.
articles.title: Russia begins second stage of tactical nuclear weapon drills with Belarus

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Four American educators from a small Iowa university were reportedly stabbed in a public park in northeast China's Jilin province over the weekend, according to U.S. media and U.S. government officials.
articles.title: Four American educators stabbed in park in northeast China, says US media and officials

articles.author: Reuters
articles.description: Former South African president Jacob Zuma's uMkhonto we Sizwe (MK) party has filed an application in the constitutional court to try to block the first sitting of the National Assembly since last month's election, it said on Tuesday.
articles.title: Zuma's MK party tries to block new South African parliament from convening

articles.author: Stephanie Van Den Berg
articles.description: The International Criminal Court's chief prosecutor is urgently investigating allegations of war crimes and crimes against humanity in the Darfur city of al-Fashir which has become a new front between the Sudanese army and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF).
articles.title: ICC prosecutor warns of war crimes committed in Darfur's al-Fashir

articles.author: Andreas Rinke, Olena Harmash
articles.description: Ukraine and its allies drummed up support to protect Ukrainian cities from Russian missiles at a conference in Berlin on Tuesday and rallied international businesses to put their faith, and billions of dollars, into post-war reconstruction.
articles.title: Ukraine drums up support to shield and rebuild shattered cities
